headline: Roberto De Zerbi sensationally leaves Marseille after being tipped for Man Utd job
body: De Zerbi has left Marseille after the weekend's defeat to PSG(Image: Getty Images)

Roberto De Zerbi has left Marseille after the 5-0 mauling at the hands of Paris Saint-Germain. The Italian was reportedly close to leaving the club last month, having reportedly handed in his resignation just days before the transfer window closed.
But De Zerbi has now actually left, with his final match in charge coming in the form of the thumping at the hands of the Ligue 1 champions on Sunday.

A statement from Marseille on Wednesday read: “Olympique de Marseille and Roberto De Zerbi, coach of the first team, announce the end of their collaboration by mutual agreement. Following discussions involving all stakeholders in the club's management – owner, president, director of football, and coach – it was decided to opt for a change at the helm of the first team.
“This was a difficult, collective decision, reached after careful consideration and in the best interests of the club to address the sporting challenges of the final stretch of the season.

“Olympique de Marseille would like to thank Roberto De Zerbi for his investment, commitment, professionalism and seriousness, marked in particular by the 2nd place obtained during the 2024/25 season. The club wishes him all the best for the rest of his career.”

De Zerbi was appointed by Marseille in 2024 following an impressive spell with Brighton. He leaves the club fourth in Ligue 1 but already 12 points behind leaders PSG.
The Italian’s exit comes amid links with a number of Premier League clubs. He has been consistently linked with the role at Tottenham Hotspur, with the pressure continuing to rise on Thomas Frank.

headline: Michael Carrick singles out Man Utd star in immediate aftermath of West Ham draw
body: Man Utd boss Michael Carrick after the 1-1 draw with West Ham

Michael Carrick hailed Leny Yoro's exceptional one-on-one defending, which allowed Manchester United to snatch a crucial draw at West Ham. The Red Devils' winning run ended at four matches, but were able to earn a point after Benjamin Sesko's 96th minute equaliser.

Yoro was brought on to replace Harry Maguire at the same time as Sesko came on for Matheus Cunha, with a quarter of the match left at the London Stadium. Despite West Ham having several glorious chances to extend their lead, 20-year-old Yoro made two critical blocks to keep his side in contention.
This marked the first time Yoro had seen action during Carrick's five-match tenure, but his contributions were pivotal when Sesko's superb strike secured the point that extended the unbeaten streak.

We had moments, Josh had a chance, obviously Casemiro had the [disallowed goal], which I've not seen, but must have been close and then big moment for Ben. Carrick's perfect run as United boss ended against the Hammers, leaving him with conflicting emotions following the final whistle. However, he remained upbeat about certain aspects of the performance, particularly as his team netted late for the fifth consecutive match.

"Mixed feelings, we know we weren't quite at our best, I think credit to West Ham, a little bit of closing certain spaces up, but I think we can be better, the boys are a bit frustrated and disappointed with that, which is a really good sign for me," he said.

"Then finishing with a late goal when we've had to find one is a good moment and another positive for us to know that we can do that. We don't want to have to pull on it and use it too often but I think in the grand scheme I think there's points we can take and we kind of dust ourselves down a little bit, assess it, take these games over a five game period and to just have one draw in there I think is a big positive so mixed feelings really."

headline: Man Utd news: Kobbie Mainoo transfer plan surprise as Marcus Rashford return stance clear
body: Kobbie Mainoo and Marcus Rashford's Manchester United futures have both been under the microscope(Image: Getty Images)

There's a reinvigorated spirit at Manchester United thanks to the arrival of Michael Carrick. The former Red Devils midfielder only returned to Old Trafford a month ago following Ruben Amorim's sacking but has instilled confidence in a squad that sorely lacked it.

United's chances of qualifying for Champions League football have drastically increased under the interim head coach following his bright start to life at the helm. While there are 12 games still to play for United, attention towards the summer continues to grow each day.

headline: Man Utd break West Ham hearts in Fergie time - but fans finally have some hope
body: Benjamin Sesko earned Man Utd a late, late point at West Ham
The wait for Manchester United goes on. But at least they salvaged a point with Benjamin Sesko’s 96th minute leveller which was straight out of the Fergie time play book.

It broke West Ham hearts and could not actually provide the fifth straight win which United have waited so long for. No-one went home happy. However, West Ham are showing signs of life and fight even if they could not see this one out for the precious three points they needed.

They did, however, stop United winning five games in a row for the first time in two years on a rollercoaster night of emotions. The long-suffering travelling United fans have seen such an improvement under Carrick and he has put in one hell of an audition to get the job on a permanent basis.

But this was also about West Ham scrapping and fighting as Nuno Espirito Santo has really begun to give the fans hope. They had to weather long spells of United pressure but West Ham refused to buckle on a grey, misty night at the London Stadium.

United went close after 22 minutes when Bruno Fernandes ’ 22nd minute corner found Luke Shaw in the box and the United defender’s shot was cleared off the line by Aaron Wan-Bissaka.
It felt like this game was going nowhere. It was drab, uneventful and you can bet England boss Thomas Tuchel probably felt like he had wasted a night as he was sat up in the stands.

But, at long last, West Ham are showing signs of fight and their opening goal was testament to teamwork. Jarrod Bowen was so clever as the West Ham captain battled and held off Shaw to create space for Tomas Soucek to ping the ball forward.
Tomas Soucek thought he has scored the winner for West Ham(Image: West Ham United FC/West Ham United FC via Getty Images)
Bowen scampered down the right wing, sent over a low cross and there was Soucek in the six yard box to turn the ball home from close range in the 50th minute.
That brought the stadium to life and even the mood in the place has changed because the home fans can sense fresh optimism and genuine hope for survival.
There was another big reason for West Ham fans to celebrate after Casemiro headed in what looked to be an equaliser but it was ruled out by VAR as the United midfielder was clearly offside.

United threw on a raft of substitutes - including Sesko - as they fought desperately for a leveller and Joshua Zirkzee came as close as anyone as he glanced just wide. That had Carrick on his toes on the touchline.

Seven minutes of added time were ticking down when United launched yet another attack - and this time it finally worked. Then just when it looked as if West Ham would get the points, Bryan Mbeumo’s ball was turned in with a looping shot from Sesko.

headline: Benjamin Sesko saves Man Utd with last-gasp goal but West Ham end run - 5 talking points
body: Benjamin Sesko salvaged a draw at the death(Image: James Fearn/Getty Images)

Benjamin Sesko's 96th-minute equaliser broke West Ham hearts and rescued a 1-1 draw for Manchester United. Tomas Soucek's second-half strike looked to have made the difference, and a victory would've taken Nuno Espirito Santo's men within three goals of escaping the relegation zone.

But Sesko, having come off the bench, came up with a magnificent finish to convert Bryan Mbeumo's cross and salvage a point. Michael Carrick had returned to his former club looking to make it five wins in a row, but despite the draw, he got some more late joy to keep the Red Devils in the top four.
Here are five talking points from the London Stadium.

If you missed the opening 45 minutes, you didn't miss much. Pedestrian football from both sides meant that chances were few and far between, with Senne Lammens having the most work to do of the goalkeepers when he palmed away a decent effort from the in-form Crysencio Summerville.

The visitors went closest, though, as Aaron Wan-Bissaka blocked Luke Shaw's effort on the line after another well-worked corner routine by Carrick's side. They had more of the possession but rarely kept it in the final third, allowing West Ham to constantly get bodies back.
To illustrate the lack of goalmouth action, the teams only generated a combined 0.28 expected goals. It was comfortably the worst half of Carrick's short reign up to that point.

Michael Carrick had some thinking to do at the break(Image: Ian Kington/AFP via Getty Images)
But was this about to be an even worse half for Carrick? After Luke Shaw hesistated and allowed on a punt forward to bounce, Jarrod Bowen won the ball and laid it off to Soucek.

The Czech had time and space to give it back to Bowen, who burst away down the right flank as claret shirts flooded the box. After a low cross, Soucek was there to tap home, completing a lovely move with his team-mate and finally giving those inside the London Stadium a reason to make some noise.

It was Soucek's third goal against the Red Devils, having also netted at Old Trafford last season. The midfielder's strike also makes him the highest-scoring Czech player in Premier League history, surpassing Patrick Berger.
Tomas Soucek combined with Jarrod Bowen to score(Image: West Ham United FC/West Ham United FC via Getty Images)

The Red Devils responded well to West Ham's opener and looked to be level just after the hour mark. Kobbie Mainoo produced a superb cross to find Casemiro charging into the penalty area and he coolly headed home past Mads Hermansen, edging in front of Wan-Bissaka.
But from Casemiro's reaction, he knew what was coming. A VAR check confirmed the offside and remained 1-0 going into the closing stages.
Casemiro looked to have equalised with a header(Image: Izzy Poles - AMA/Getty Images)

By no means an outcast under Ruben Amorim, Harry Maguire's return from injury coincided with Carrick's appointment and has given him a new lease of life. Imperious for much of the last five games, there was a moment of worry in the first half when the 32-year-old went into a tackle and came out clutching his hamstring.

Maguire was able to continue until being subbed in the 68th minute alongside Matheus Cunha, who'd been ineffective, and he was seen talking to staff. Leny Yoro and Benjamin Sesko were sent on while Nuno also made a change, as Callum Wilson replaced Valentin Castellanos.
Harry Maguire was feeling his hamstring in the first half(Image: James Fearn/Getty Images)

After coming up with the winner against Fulham two games ago, Sesko was the Red Devils' saviour again - and this time in style. As Carrick threw the kitchen sink at it, West Ham had multiple chances to finish the game off.

And the Irons were left to rue their careless finishing when Sesko met Mbeumo's cross at the near post and found the top right-hand corner. Carrick's winning run is over but the honeymoon period might just continue in nearly a fortnight's time at Everton.

headline: Viral Man Utd fan left 'heartbroken' on live stream as haircut plan dashed by West Ham
body: A Manchester United fan who went viral for refusing to cut his hair until the Red Devils win five matches in a row will have to wait at least another month for his trip to the barbers. The 'United Strand' was hoping that his 493-day challenge would finally come to an end on Tuesday evening, with just one win remaining on the Red Devils' part.

That's given United had achieved wins over Manchester City, Arsenal, Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur on-the-bounce ahead of their trip to the London Stadium to face West Ham United. However, as they were held to a 1-1 draw by the Hammers in the capital, the viral sensation's tally reset, and he will now rely on United going another five matches without a loss or a draw.

The 'United Strand, real name Frank Ilett, was left with egg on his face as he took part in an event on live stream platform Kick for the match, his ever-growing hair sitting on the shoulders of a retro Red Devils shirt. After a goalless first-half, Tomas Soucek looked to have crushed the hopes and dreams of the social media star 50 minutes into the match, putting West Ham 1-0 up on home soil.

An incredibly cagey final 40 plus stoppage time then played out, as the weight of the result grew heavier than the luscious locks upon his head. While Benjamin Sesko levelled the match six minutes into stoppage time, it was a case of too little, too late for United, who walked away from the London Stadium sharing the points with the Hammers.

While the result will have felt like a win to United fans watching around the world, given just how far out of the fixture the Red Devils were, it will have came as a crushing blow to Ilett, who will now have to wait until at least March 20 to book his trip to the barbers.

Furthermore, United will have to secure victory over Everton, Crystal Palace, Newcastle United, Aston Villa and Bournemouth to allow the 'United Strand' to finally shave his head. It marks another long 38 day wait for Ilett, who may see his challenge draw to a close on day 531 if he is lucky.
Clearly gutted by the result, Ilett was speechless as the full-time whistle blew. However, he did manage to muster some words to his fans in the aftermath.

He said: "It's tough. It's tough to think, really. We go again, I guess.
"The main positive is that the hair gets a bit longer for the Little Princess Trust and I can donate it, that's what they want. It's just tough, I really felt this was it.
"But we keep going, we keep committed. See you on Day 500. Got to do something special for that now."

The draw also marked the first time that Michael Carrick has failed to pick up a victory in his interim head coaching tenure with Manchester United. Up next for the Red Devils is a trip to Hill Dickinson Stadium to face Everton come Monday, February 23.

headline: Rio Ferdinand shuts down Roy Keane theory as Kobbie Mainoo thrives at Man Utd
body: Kobbie Mainoo has looked sharp since returning to the Manchester United starting XI(Image: Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)

Rio Ferdinand has pointed out how Kobbie Mainoo's displays since returning to the Manchester United team under Michael Carrick have demolished a claim Roy Keane made about the midfielder earlier in the season.

Prior to Carrick's appointment as United's interim manager until the campaign's end, Mainoo hadn't featured from the start in the Premier League at all in 2025/26. That's now shifted with starts in all four wins since the 44-year-old took charge at Old Trafford, and fresh terms are being discussed.

Emphasising the 20-year-old's revival, he successfully completed 33 of 35 attempted final-third passes during United's 2-0 triumph over Tottenham Hotspur, topping the division in this metric last weekend.
This specific aspect of Mainoo's game had previously been challenged by former United boss Ruben Amorim, whilst the England international's commitment had been questioned by United icon Keane.
"The word coming out is they don't think he can cover the ground that quickly, but if you look at Man Utd's other midfielders they've got, they're not great at that either.
"As a young player, he has to suck that up and work hard, and when he gets a chance, he has to take it.

"A young player with good potential cannot be guaranteed a place in United's team. But it will come down to the player himself. Your job every day, every week, is to make sure the manager puts you in the team.
"If the manager deep down doesn't fancy him? I don't know. We will find that out in the next few weeks. Because if he doesn't fancy him, he might have to move him on."

Fast-forward to February 2026, and fellow United icon Ferdinand reckons the young midfielder's commitment in training should never have been questioned.

"We asked the question. 'Is he working? Is he doing what the manager is asking him? Is he putting physical mileage on the training ground?' There's no doubt in my mind that you run the amount that he has; it's concrete that he was working when he wasn't in the team," the former defender said, speaking on his Rio Ferdinand Presents podcast.
"The tank is empty at 60 minutes, you are on the floor when you haven't been playing for a while, and then you start. He must be doing some real work. I tip my hat to Kobbie Mainoo."
Also weighing in on the matter following United's fourth straight Premier League win was Gary Lineker, who went so far as to joke Mainoo ought to consider suing his previous manager Amorim.
"He's taken a year out of that kid's career. This kid is a wonderful footballer," Lineker shared on The Rest is Football podcast.
"God, he makes it look so easy. He wants the ball, he receives it with anyone around him and he turns, always makes the right decisions, he's graceful.
"I mean, come on! He's been absolutely detrimental to his career."

headline: Man Utd 'make final Harry Maguire contract decision' after Michael Carrick move
body: Michael Carrick has put his trust in Harry Maguire(Image: Shaun Brooks - CameraSport, CameraSport via Getty Images)

Harry Maguire appears highly likely to secure a new deal with Manchester United in the coming months, as Michael Carrick continues to instil faith in the centre-back. The England international will be 33 when his existing agreement expires this summer, as he approaches the latter stages of his career.

Given that he's understood to currently earn approximately £180,000-per-week in wages, United may seek to reduce his salary as they attempt to reach an arrangement with him. The club will also need to negotiate with his representatives regarding the duration of his new deal.

The England international has proved integral to Carrick's system at Old Trafford and now looks set to have his tenure prolonged following his impressive displays in recent weeks. The Daily Mail report Maguire's representatives held discussions with AC Milan in January, though the player wishes to remain and appears likely to pen new terms.

Maguire has featured in every one of Carrick's matches since taking charge of United last month, partnering alongside Lisandro Martinez in victories over Manchester City, Arsenal, Fulham and Tottenham.

Should Maguire finalise a new agreement with his club of seven years, it would represent a remarkable turnaround from the situation he encountered just a number of years ago, having been relieved of his captaincy by Erik ten Hag before drifting in and out of Ruben Amorim's starting XI.

Maguire's situation differs from that of team-mate Casemiro, who has confirmed he will leave Manchester United when his contract runs out this summer. The Brazilian holding midfielder has flourished at the Theatre of Dreams since joining from Real Madrid in 2022, clocking up 149 appearances in the heart of the engine room.

Nevertheless, the 33-year-old revealed earlier this year that he will be departing the Reds this summer. Taking to Instagram to share the poignant announcement, he wrote: "Knowing when stages come to an end.
Casemiro will leave Manchester United this summer(Image: Visionhaus/Getty Images)

The move came despite Casemiro possessing a contract extension option in his existing agreement, triggered should he feature in 35 matches or more this campaign. Both Casemiro and Maguire will be aiming to secure a fifth consecutive victory under Carrick on Tuesday evening, as the Reds head to the London Stadium to face a rejuvenated West Ham United.

headline: Unai Emery sends clear message to Man Utd on Aston Villa completing Jadon Sancho transfer
body: Aston Villa manager Unai Emery is not yet convinced by Jadon Sancho(Image: David Horton/Getty Images)

Jadon Sancho is playing for his future at Aston Villa because Unai Emery remains undecided whether to sign the Manchester United winger permanently. Sancho in on loan from United with Villa and has enjoyed a decent period of form of late.

The 25-year-old began the season as part of the bomb squad at United, with Ruben Amorim freezing out Sancho, Marcus Rashford, Tyrell Malacia, Alejandro Garnacho and Antony. Villa decided to sign him on a season-long loan deal in the hope he could repeat his form at Borussia Dortmund.

That did not materialise in the early stages of the season, with zero goals or assists coming until January 22, when Sancho broke his duck by scoring in a 1-0 win over Fenerbahce. He then assisted Morgan Rogers in the 1-1 draw against Bournemouth on the weekend, prompting reporters to ask Emery about Sancho's future.

The Villa boss said he "expects more" from Sancho after the draw against Bournemouth. And speaking ahead of Villa's Premier League game against Brighton on Wednesday, Emery said he remained undecided on a permanent transfer for Sancho in the summer.

headline: Harry Maguire hints at biggest issue with Ruben Amorim at Man Utd as he praises team-mate
body: Harry Maguire has highlighted the biggest improvement Manchester United have made since Michael Carrick took over - and his comments hint at where Ruben Amorim went wrong. Carrick has won all four of his matches since replacing the sacked Amorim last month.

The United interim manager has changed the formation from Amorim's favoured 3-4-2-1 to a more simplistic 4-2-3-1 and has reaped the benefits. United have beaten Manchester City, Arsenal, Fulham and Tottenham to turn around their fortunes and solidify fourth place in the Premier League.

Carrick has stuck with a settled side, using Kobbie Mainoo in midfield alongside Casemiro and allowing Bruno Fernandes to play as a No.10. Maguire has re-established his partnership with Lisandro Martinez in central defence and is delighted with the upturn in form.

He believes that the defensive structure and organisation that Carrick has drilled into the players has made all the difference as they go in search of their fifth straight win against West Ham on Tuesday night.

headline: Marcus Rashford rumour addressed as Gary Lineker makes prediction about Man Utd ace
body: Gary Lineker has predicted Marcus Rashford will play a prominent role for England at World Cup 2026 amid rumours of a Manchester United comeback(Image: Getty Images)

Gary Lineker has predicted Marcus Rashford deserves a starting spot in England's XI at this year's World Cup. The former Match of the Day host made the assertion while addressing speculation surrounding Rashford's future at Manchester United.

Reports have surfaced suggesting interim United manager Michael Carrick is keen to bring the forward back to Old Trafford following the conclusion of his loan at Barcelona. However, it's believed Rashford is hesitant about returning to his boyhood club, where he hasn't featured since December 2024.

Speaking to Spanish football expert Alex Aljoe on The Rest Is Football, Lineker praised Rashford for his latest Barcelona performance. The Englishman was in the starting line-up as the Blaugrana demolished Mallorca 3-0 on Saturday, with Robert Lewandowski, Lamine Yamal and Marc Bernal providing the goals.

"I want to start with someone who didn't score but got a lot of plaudits, and that's Marcus Rashford," he said. "Because he's been in the news a little bit, that there's a rumour that Michael Carrick wants Rashford to go back.

"And the rumour was that he actually doesn't want to go back. He's pretty happy. I saw a post this morning saying, 'Well played, Marcus. What a performance.' If you look at England [and] who plays on the left for England. I think at the moment, Rashford's miles ahead."

Anthony Gordon was put forward as another option, with the Newcastle ace poised to compete for Thomas Tuchel's left wing position. Morgan Rogers and Noni Madueke might also be viewed as contenders for that berth, but Lineker reckons Rashford holds the advantage.

"Rashford's been really, really good," he added. "And of course, it's a big advantage the way they play in Spain, that it's not so physically demanding. That come the World Cup, he won't be knackered like most of the players playing in the Premier League [laughs]."
Lineker continues to be impressed by Rashford's exploits at Barcelona(Image: The Rest Is Football)

His most recent appearance in La Liga ended Rashford's run of finding the net in consecutive matches. He delivered the club's consolation goal in a 2-1 loss to Real Sociedad last month before scoring in a 3-1 triumph at Elche.

The 28-year-old has netted 10 goals and registered 13 assists in 34 appearances for Barca in all competitions. Nevertheless, it remains uncertain whether Hansi Flick has been persuaded to activate the permanent clause to acquire the player for roughly £26million as of yet.

Should Barcelona decline to exercise the buy option, Rashford will head back to Manchester in comparable circumstances to last summer. However, the crucial distinction is that it might be Carrick, rather than Ruben Amorim, making the decisions this time round.

headline: 13 stars at risk of missing World Cup 2026 including Neymar, Alexander Isak and Bryan Mbeumo
body: Neymar is at risk of missing out on a place in the Brazil squad for the World Cup(Image: (Photo by Ana Julia Guerreiro/Eurasia Sport Images/Getty Images))

The World Cup is where many of the greatest players in history have cemented their legacies. But for every Leo Messi at Qatar 2022, there is a George Weah, Ryan Giggs or Eric Cantona - players who never appeared on the biggest stage during their glittering careers.

With many domestic seasons in full tilt, there will be players cruelly axed from the biggest ever World Cup in North America due to injuries and lack of form. And the play-offs in March provide further jeopardy for more high-profile stars who could potentially miss out on the 48-team tournament.
Here's a look at some of the biggest stars who risk missing out on the tournament, or have already missed their chance to book tickets for the World Cup.

Neymar has been lauded as one of the best players of his generation, and for good reason. The forward could light up a game with the sort of trickery that has become well associated with the top stars coming out of Brazil.

However, now at 34 years of age, there is growing uncertainty over his place in the national team ahead of what could be his final World Cup. Neymar has been struggling with injury issues over the past few seasons, and while a return to Santos came with the hope of rebounding, it hasn't quite had that effect - yet.

Carlo Ancelotti has made it clear that he won't be carrying players through the tournament, however, as the barrage of questions over the star's possible inclusion in the squad continue. It means Neymar has an uphill battle to be among those on the plane to the World Cup this summer, just 12 years on from making his bow in his home tournament.

SANTOS, BRAZIL - DECEMBER 7: Neymar Junior of Santos looks on during the Brasileirao 2025 match between Santos and Cruzeiro at Urbano Caldeira Stadium (Vila Belmiro) on December 7, 2025 in Santos, Brazil. (Photo by Ricardo Moreira/Getty Images)(Image: (Photo by Ricardo Moreira/Getty Images))

Sweden are facing a battle to book their place at the World Cup, after a disappointing qualification campaign that ended in turmoil. The side finished bottom of their group with just two points to their name, as Switzerland, Kosovo, and Slovenia all finished above them.

With Graham Potter in interim charge, Sweden have a lifeline for the World Cup, thanks to the UEFA Nations League, which has put them in the mix for qualification. They take on Ukraine in March internationals for a place in the final of their bracket, which will be a crucial match.

Alexander Isak faces a race to get back fit and firing in time, after picking up a serious leg injury. Meanwhile, other high-profile teammates such as Arsenal's Viktor Gyokeres and injured Tottenham forward Dejan Kulusevski also face the possibility of not going to the World Cup, unless their form changes dramatically.
Cameroon missed out on qualifying for the World Cup, after a surprise exit from QAF qualifiers. The African nation have featured at six World Cups, with a quarter-final appearance in 1990.
That means stars such as Bryan Mbeumo and Carlos Baleba won't be featuring at the tournament, despite their impressive campaigns so far this season for Manchester United and Brighton.

RABAT, MOROCCO - JANUARY 9:  Bryan Mbeumo of Cameroon during the Africa Cup Of Nations Quarter-final match between Cameroon and Morocco at Prince Moulay Abdellah Stadium on January 9, 2026 in Rabat, Morocco. (Photo by Visionhaus/Getty Images)(Image: (Photo by Visionhaus/Getty Images))

It would be inconceivable to suggest that a nation with the history of Italy would miss another World Cup, and yet, that is a distinct possibility. The Azzurri haven't played in the tournament since 2014, missing the 2018 and 2022 editions through the qualification stages.

Here they are again, looking at the need to get through a play-off round to get through to the tournament for the first time in 12 years. Manchester City star Gianluigi Donnarumma, who signed from PSG for £25million last summer, gives them a chance, but the pressure that comes with needing to win the upcoming matches will test even their most notable stars.

Robert Lewandowski is a modern-day great, having shown his quality on both the club and international stage. The striker has often faced a battle to drag Poland through some tough moments, but they have managed to qualify for the past two tournaments, appearing in 2018 and 2022.

At 37, this is more than likely the final chance for Lewandowski to show his quality at the World Cup, but he risks missing out altogether. Poland will need to get past Albania in their first play-off game, before having the possibility of a one-off knockout match to book a place at the finals.

Liverpool star Dominik Szoboszlai has made himself a household name in England, ever since making his move to the Premier League. Despite his moments of individual brilliance, he won't be making an appearance with Hungary at the World Cup this summer, following a tough qualification group.

A 3-2 defeat at the hands of Ireland in the final kick of their final match ensured they won't be able to qualify, and will have to try again for 2030. Szoboszlai admitted the experience was "very tough", with the Liverpool ace left thinking what could have been for the upcoming tournament.

Dominik Szoboszlai of Hungary reacts after the third goal during the FIFA 2026 World Cup Qualifiers match at Puskas Arena in Budapest, Hungary, on November 16, 2025. (Photo by Robert Szaniszlo/NurPhoto via Getty Images)(Image: (Photo by Robert Szaniszlo/NurPhoto via Getty Images))

Kvicha Kvaratskhelia and his Georgia side excited plenty of fans during the European Championships in 2024, but there will be no repeat of that this summer. The national team failed to book their place at the World Cup this summer, after finishing third in their group.

It was a tough ask for the PSG star and his compatriots, who had Spain and Turkiye in their group, along with Bulgaria, as they picked up just three points. With no route through the play-offs available, Georgia will have to put their World Cup dreams aside for another tournament.

England have struggled to get the best out of Trent Alexander-Arnold so far, while finding a space to fit him in the team on a regular basis. The right-back was deployed in midfield at times by Gareth Southgate, who often preferred other full-backs during his tenure as the head coach.

While Thomas Tuchel is now in charge, the Real Madrid star has only received one call-up to his squad so far, coming in June 2025. With a mixture of injury issues and form concerns, there is a real chance that the 27-year-old misses out on the squad altogether for the summer.

LONDON, ENGLAND - OCTOBER 10: Trent Alexander-Arnold of England during the UEFA Nations League 2024/25 League B Group B2 match between England and Greece at Wembley Stadium on October 10, 2024 in London, England. (Photo by Robin Jones/Getty Images)(Image: (Photo by Robin Jones/Getty Images))

Wales are once again reliant on the qualification play-off route if they are to compete at the 2026 World Cup. They took it close, picking up an impressive 15 points from eight group games, but finished two points shy of the eventual winners, Belgium.

The task ahead for the home nation is a clash with Bosnia and Herzegovina, before a possible tie that will be a one-off final for a place in the tournament. Premier League stars such as Brennan Johnson, Harry Wilson, and Ethan Ampadu will be keen to fire Wales to their second consecutive World Cup, with those play-off games taking place in March.

Johnson may be the nation's main hope of qualifying, having made the move from Tottenham to Crystal Palace for £35million in the January transfer window. With an opportunity for more minutes and a return to form, he could take that momentum into the March internationals with Wales at an important time.

Mikel Merino has been a mainstay for the Spain national team, having shown quality in the midfield, and a finishing touch in the opposition box. That has translated over to his form for Arsenal, where he has played as an auxiliary striker at times, alongside his usual role as a midfielder.

While there is some hope that he will feature at the World Cup, there are doubts over his availability. Merino has picked up an injury, with a fractured bone in his foot, causing some discomfort, which will require a procedure to ensure that he can return to action as quickly as possible.
Despite those hopes, some reports in Spain have claimed that Merino could miss the rest of the season, and will be facing a race against time to get fit and available for the World Cup.

Mikel Merino central midfield of Spain and Arsenal FC during the FIFA World Cup 2026 qualifier match between Spain and Türkiye at Estadio de La Cartuja on November 18, 2025 in Seville, Spain.  (Photo by Jose Breton/Pics Action/NurPhoto via Getty Images)(Image: (Photo by Jose Breton/Pics Action/NurPhoto via Getty Images))

Northern Ireland earned themselves a chance at booking a place in the World Cup this summer by finishing as one of the best third-placed teams in the UEFA qualification stages. They managed to pick up nine points in six games in a group that included Germany, Slovakia and Luxembourg.

Their reward for that achievement... a clash with Italy in the first round of the qualification play-offs. It'll be a tough test, but one that can be done, as the Azzurri have shown through their recent downfalls in these play-off rounds.

That challenge is made tougher, however, through the absence of Conor Bradley. The defender picked up a serious knee injury that will see him out of action until next season at the earliest, with the Liverpool star only able to watch on and hope that his national team can pull off a miracle.

Turkiye have been viewed as potential dark horses in recent competitions, but they haven't quite been able to turn that into results. There is a chance to do so at the World Cup, but they will also need to get through the qualification play-offs to give themselves an opportunity to do so.

They take on Romania first up, with hope that they can lean on some of their best talent to step up and do the business. Kenan Yildiz is certainly one of those for his national team, with the youngster proving his quality for Juventus, while attracting attention from clubs across Europe.
Translating that onto the national stage would be the next step on his way to stardom, but he risks missing a World Cup if he cannot.

Denmark suffered heartbreak late on in their qualification clash with Scotland, which saw them lose their grasp on a place at the World Cup. An almighty collapse in their final two games resulted in the unlikely drop into the play-offs, where they will now face North Macedonia.

Some familiar faces are in the Denmark camp, such as Rasmus Hojlund, Christian Eriksen, and Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg. They will be leaning on that experience and quality to get them through the upcoming matches, while burying the demons that were left from their defeat to Scotland.

headline: Rio Ferdinand lifts lid on tense TNT Sports exit - 'I do my own s***'
body: Rio Ferdinand has claimed he left TNT Sport after his ideas for the channel were pushed aside. The former Manchester United defender left the channel in May last year after a decade.

He departed following his final broadcast of the 2025 Champions League final between Paris Saint-Germain and Inter Milan. He was previously a regular face of the channel’s European, Premier League and domestic cup coverage.
And he has now opened up on why he chose to depart the channel, with Ferdinand keen for a new challenge, having seen his ideas for a freshen up with the broadcasters ignored.

Speaking to Men’s Health, the former defender said: “I like being tested. I like pressure. I had it fine at TNT. I could have signed a new contract at TNT. Easily. But that ain’t who I am really. It’s time for something new.
“And with all due respect, I’d been trying to push [a new] side of things within the team and the group at TNT, and they weren’t really as receptive as I would’ve liked.
“So that was another big reason why I go, ‘Okay, if you’re not going to jump in two-footed with me and hold hands, then I move on. We’ll see how I do when I go on my own’.
“Because I saw the new world is that linear TV and live football are always going to be there, but there’s also another world outside the 90 minutes that intrigues me, which I look at like a fan.
“So I want to know what the f*** these guys are eating, how do they sleep, how do they recover? I want to get the public closer to that and I want to be at the forefront of that.
“But at the same time, this is just who I am. I’m not trying to be no one, I’m me. I do my own s***. I’ve always been in my own lane.”

Since Ferdinand’s exit from TNT, he has continued his post-footballing career through a number of ventures. He has his own YouTube channel, where he regularly analyses the latest news from former club Man United. Ferdinand was also part of the draw for the 2026 World Cup.

The former defender rounded off his career in football in 2015 following a brief spell with Queens Park Rangers. Before that, he spent 12 glittering seasons with Man United, winning six league titles and the Champions League under legendary boss Sir Alex Ferguson. Ferdinand also earned 81 appearances for England during his playing career.

headline: Kobbie Mainoo plan had Man Utd's rivals 'in disbelief' before Michael Carrick decision
body: Kobbie Mainoo has started four games under Michael Carrick(Image: Photo by Mike Morese/MI News/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

Manchester United's rumoured willingness to loan out Kobbie Mainoo for the remainder of the campaign has reportedly stunned several Premier League sides, as well as Napoli. Mainoo struggled during the opening months of the season under former boss Ruben Amorim and failed to earn a single Premier League start before the Portuguese manager's exit in December.

At one point, Mainoo appeared destined for a loan move, until interim boss Michael Carrick stepped in. Napoli were particularly eager to bring the 21 year old in on a temporary basis for the rest of the season, whilst the midfielder also caught the eye of Tottenham, Aston Villa and Everton.

Scott McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund have both joined Napoli - McTominay on a permanent transfer and Hojlund on loan - and the duo have flourished since departing Old Trafford. Napoli manager Antonio Conte was keen to add another United player to his ranks following their impressive form.

According to The Telegraph, there was 'genuine disbelief' in Naples that United were even considering allowing Mainoo to leave. Similar sentiments were reportedly echoed by 'many Premier League clubs' who had expressed interest in securing the youngster on loan.

Throughout Amorim's tenure, the 41-year-old frequently emphasised his desire for players to 'stay and fight' rather than abandon ship at the first hint of difficulty - taking aim at what he perceived as an 'entitlement' mentality amongst certain academy graduates.

He had also pointed to Casemiro as a prime example of a player who changed his attitude and battled his way back into the starting XI, stating: "When I see Casemiro training, if everyone trains like him, if everyone is so focused on the detail, even in training, in set-pieces training, even when they are playing ten versus goalkeeper, and the movements that he made, imagining the game, we will be a top team.

"If everyone works like Casemiro, and when I say work it's not just running, it's that focus. You can understand why that guy won five Champions Leagues, because if you pay attention to everything that he does with contract, with no contract, he's top player."
Many interpreted this as another thinly-veiled dig at Mainoo.
Kobbie Mainoo in action for Man United(Image: Getty Images)
The Mirror also revealed that, following Carrick's appointment, Mainoo was informed he would feature in the squad for the rest of the campaign.
This came with explicit instructions to concentrate on winning back his place at his boyhood club, whilst demonstrating that Amorim had made a mistake in sidelining him.
Since Carrick took charge, Mainoo has been named in the starting line-up against Manchester City, Arsenal, Fulham and Tottenham.
He is also expected to be in the frame to start their fixture at relegation-battling West Ham on Tuesday night (8pm).

headline: Jose Mourinho 'to be offered dream job' in boost for Ruben Amorim after Man Utd sacking
body: Ruben Amorim could replace Jose Mourinho at Benfica in the summer(Image: Carlos Rodrigues/Getty Images)

Jose Mourinho will reportedly be offered the Portugal manager's job after Roberto Martinez steps down following the World Cup. Mourinho is currently in charge of Benfica but has previously made it clear that he would love to manage his country, opening up the possibility of another high-profile role for the 63-year-old.

Martinez is preparing to lead Portugal at the World Cup, which kicks off in Canada, the United States and Mexico on June 11. Like many international bosses, including Thomas Tuchel with England, his contract will expire at the end of the tournament.

The Portuguese Football Federation (FPF) is therefore planning ahead and has reportedly made Mourinho the top choice to replace Martinez. Mourinho signed a two-year contract when he joined Benfica in September following his exit from Fenerbahce, but ESPN says the FPF will try and lure him into international management for the first time in the summer.

That possibility would open up the Benfica role for Ruben Amorim, who is currently without a job after being sacked by United at the start of January. Amorim's reputation has taken a hit in the Premier League, but he remains highly regarded in his home country and would be the top pick for Benfica if they lose Mourinho, given his success at Sporting Lisbon and the fact he spent nine years there as a player.

Mourinho has been at the top level of club management for over 20 years, taking charge of Porto, Chelsea, Real Madrid, Inter Milan, Manchester United, Tottenham, Roma, Fenerbahce and Benfica. But he is yet to taste international management and has made it clear that he would only consider doing so with Portugal.

"I want to play a European Championship or a World Cup and unite a country around a team, as I have already done many times with the clubs," he said in an interview with Corriere Dello Sport in January last year while still at Fenerbahce. "I want to do it for football and what this sport represents. It will be incredible."

Then, when linked with the Brazil job - which eventually went to Carlo Ancelotti - he said: "My destiny, in terms of internationals, is to play in a World Cup with the Portuguese national team. I never considered coaching the Brazilian national team.
Jose Mourinho was appointed by Benfica earlier this season(Image: Getty Images)

"My first experience has to be with Portugal, and then people have to understand that I'm a professional and that I can coach other teams, but always teams with which I have something that connects me.

"Brazil, obviously, because of the historical relationship between our countries, England because it's my home, Italy, I worked there for several years, but my first experience with the national team has to be mine."

Benfica are currently third in the Portuguese top flight, seven points adrift of leaders Porto and three behind Sporting. They face a two-legged play-off against Real Madrid for a place in the last 16 of the Champions League following a dramatic 4-2 win over Los Blancos in the final game of the group stage last month.

headline: Man Utd star's meeting with Sandro Tonali as he gave Newcastle midfielder transfer advice
body: Sandro Tonali is reportedly on Manchester United's radar(Image: OLI SCARFF, AFP via Getty Images)

Sandro Tonali once received transfer counsel from a Manchester United ace before a high-profile move. Newcastle's Italian midfielder is being linked with a switch to Old Trafford this summer, as United look to bolster their midfield options, particularly with Casemiro poised to depart.

A return to Italy with Juventus has also been suggested, while Manchester City are reportedly keeping tabs on the situation, according to the Telegraph. Tonali's representative recently added fuel to the fire by revealing his client is contemplating his future, sparking concern among Newcastle supporters that one of Eddie Howe's key players might leave.

Tonali has faced significant decisions in his career before, including during his breakout period at Brescia. Numerous top Italian clubs were vying for his signature, including Juventus, where Man United's Matthijs de Ligt was playing at the time.

As he deliberated over his future, the pair happened to meet in a restaurant, where Tonali discussed his impending decision. He told Cronache in March last year: "We were in Sardinia, Cistana, Torregrossa, and I, the Brescia group, basically. We met De Ligt at a restaurant.

"It was the year we played against each other in Serie A, the year of Covid. He spoke highly of Juventus. As a player, he advised me to consider it.

"Those were the days when I was negotiating with AC Milan. We stopped to talk after a game. Sometimes, for a handful of seconds, you find yourself chatting with an opponent even if you don't know them, more out of respect.
"Some of them you memorise and when you see them, you think, 'I've seen this before.' It was the summer I ended up in the newspapers because it was difficult for me to return to Serie B with Brescia.

"AC Milan, Inter and Juventus were up for grabs all summer. So everyone was telling me, 'Come to Inter, come to AC Milan, come to Juventus.'"

Tonali, who would ultimately sign for AC Milan rather than Juve, was recently linked with a deadline day transfer to Arsenal, though Newcastle were quick to confirm no discussions had taken place and Howe subsequently indicated his desire to retain his £55million signing.

headline: Michael Carrick showed his true colours in Man Utd dressing room clash - 'He was raging'
body: Michael Carrick showed his boss he's not easily unsettled(Image: Photo by Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)

Michael Carrick was once on the wrong side of Sir Alex Ferguson's infamous hairdryer treatment at Manchester United - but showed his mettle by staying silent and not letting the harsh criticism get the better of him.

The current Man United interim boss received his dressing-down while the Red Devils were in action against Ecuadorian side Liga de Quito in the Club World Cup in Yokohama, after beating Chelsea in the 2008 Champions League final in Moscow.

Throughout the final, legendary United boss Ferguson had been on at Carrick to move the ball forward more regularly. The midfielder, whose playing career started at United's opponents this Tuesday, West Ham, insists all but one of his passes were played forward - the one that Ferguson remembered.

The Scot lost his temper on the touchline, and Carrick came in for one hell of a talking to at half-time. Writing in his autobiography, Between the Lines, Carrick said: "The moment I entered the changing room, the boss launched into me. 'Pass the ball f***ing forward, I f***ing told you'. Sir Alex was raging.
"When he was like that, you had to sit there and take it, let him blow off some steam. On the outside, I was calm, nodding at the boss's points, hiding my anger.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UTD FB PAGE! Latest United news and more on our dedicated Facebook page

"On the inside, I was fuming, saying to myself, 'I must have played 40 passes forward here, and he's picked the one where I've gone back'. But the boss was so wound up that I didn't dare voice my defence."

A Wayne Rooney goal saw United win the match 1-0, despite centre-back Nemanja Vidic being shown a red card. And Carrick remained an important player for Ferguson, with the Scot later admitting he always thought highly of the midfielder.
A big reason for this, as the Scot would explain, is that Carrick showed incredible maturity early on in his career when leaving the north east for West Ham at such a young age.
Ferguson said: "One of the things that stuck out to me when we were profiling him and preparing to make a bid was that as a young boy, 16 years of age, he left home to play for West Ham.
Manchester United are flying under Michael Carrick(Image: James Gill/Danehouse)
"That tells you that the boy had the confidence that he was going to make it. A 16-year-old kid from Newcastle going to east London, that's a trek, and it impressed me.

"From the minute we bought Michael in 2006, his character has always been outstanding. He's a football man, and that character, coupled with his ability, made him a certainty to be a big success at United."
Carrick has the opportunity to make it five wins from five against West Ham, which would see the Red Devils leapfrog Aston Villa in third ahead of their game against Brighton on Wednesday.
And he's in a buoyant mood ahead of the trip to east London. He said: "You've got to enjoy the buzz of winning, that's what we're in it for.
"You can't just be flat-lined all the time. You have to feel the waves of emotion. It would all be a little bit boring and pointless if you didn't, because winning games is what we all strive for.
"The big challenge is knowing the hard work and preparation that has got you there. Winning a game of football at this level is tough, so you never assume the next one's just going to be all right."

headline: What ex-Man Utd stars have said about Michael Carrick appointment as Roy Keane called out
body: Michael Carrick has had a great impact at Manchester United(Image: Getty Images)

The debate around Michael Carrick’s Manchester United future continues to roll on. The former Red Devils midfielder was appointed last month as Ruben Amorim’s replacement on a deal until the end of the season.

The idea was for Carrick to stabilise the ship ahead of stepping down in favour of a more high-profile name. But he has outperformed that original remit, leading the club to four consecutive wins, with many now clamouring for him to be given the role on a full-term basis.

A number of former United stars have offered their take on a potential appointment, with some suggesting he should be a shoo-in. Other ex-Red Devils have claimed that club chiefs should stick to the original plan.
With that being said, take a look at what every former United star has said when it comes to Carrick’s future at Old Trafford:
FOLLOW OUR MAN UTD FB PAGE! Latest United news and more on our dedicated Facebook page
Let’s start with the man himself. Carrick has regularly been asked about his take on the long-term Man United hotseat.
And while he might have ambitions, he has kept them close to his chest. Speaking last week, he said: “I'm fully aware of the role I'm doing here and the responsibility I've got.
“We want to be successful, and I want the club to be successful beyond the end of the season - if that's me, if that's somebody else.

“At this stage, I can't control that and we'll see what happens, but it's certainly about trying to improve the team and making Manchester United stronger. Results over a short period of time don't change that.”
Carrick has regularly spoken out on his role(Image: Getty Images)

Pundit Gary Neville has never been afraid to share his opinion on the goings on at Old Trafford - and Carrick’s future is no different. Speaking just after the midfielder was given the job, he claimed that he should only fulfill his original remit.
"I hope he does really well," Neville said on the Stick to Football podcast. "There cannot be any consideration that Michael takes the job beyond this season, for Michael and for the club.

"If he wins every game, look, we could be sat here in the season where he's done unbelievably well, and we're always thinking the fans are up and they're in the Champions League places, fifth or whatever. It could happen if there's a good run and we could all be getting swayed with it.
"I honestly feel like [you have to look at others] at the end of the season when you've got [Mauricio] Pochettino, [Thomas] Tuchel and [Carlo] Ancelotti.
Gary Neville has shared his insight on United's search for a new manager(Image: Getty Images)
"I've said Ancelotti. I just feel purely because he's 66 years of age, he's got probably the best job in the world right now. He's probably got one job left at club level.
"If there's one person who's got the patience, the composure, the experience of the Premier League."

Meanwhile, Neville has since revealed that the Red Devils have already gotten the process of finding Carrick’s eventual replacement underway. He said: "I asked the club what is the official position of the football club in terms of what you're saying publicly to everybody else.
“I have to say I thought their answer was pretty good. They said they've actually begun the process now, starting to look for another manager, which I thought right.”

With Neville being against Carrick’s long-term appointment, he can count Roy Keane among the colleagues to agree with him. Speaking after his initial arrival, the Irishman said that United needed the ‘best of the best’.

He has since softened on that stance, but still believes that United should look elsewhere. He said: “I don't think it's the right decision, good luck with it. Yeah, but, I'm sticking to my guns. I've said my piece, I think that he's got the job, and if he gets it in the summer then you go ‘listen, good luck to him’, but as a caretaker manager, it's a different animal to being manager of United trying to win league titles over the next two, three, four, five years, whatever it might be

“I think you can get a better manager than Carrick, absolutely. But I think he's doing a good job, perfect timing for him, and even if he doesn't get the United job, these results a bit like Ruud (Van Nistelrooy), he can get another job, probably another Premiership manager.

“But just cause you're doing well at United, it doesn't mean he'll do well at another club. He's got the players back, it's all been sliding doors moments. Great for him, and he's took advantage of it.”
Roy Keane has taken a brutal stance when it comes to Michael Carrick(Image: Getty Images)

Former defender Ferdinand has responded to those claims and suggested that he can’t wrap his head around Keane’s comments. He said: “No matter what Michael Carrick does, how well he does, and if he got the job on the back of a great ending to the season, there's still risk.
“There's an element of risk, but with every one of the names that get thrown into the hat, there an element of risk with all of them.

“I don't know in any walk of life, where someone comes in given the opportunity to do well, and put their first foot forward for a job opportunity, they smash it - and hopefully he carries on, at the moment he’s smashing it, four wins out of four, and people are going ‘no, he shouldn’t get it though’.
“I don't understand that with Roy, I've got to be honest. I don't know how you can be so against it.”

His former defensive colleague Stam has also shared his thoughts on the Red Devils’ search for a new manager and suggested that former Brighton boss Roberto De Zerbi would be an excellent candidate instead of Carrick.

He said: "I like De Zerbi very much, you know, because of how he performed at Brighton and also now in Marseille. How he's playing with his teams, because he plays possession-based football, he's very good on the ball.

"He also sets the players in certain positions that it makes it really difficult for the opposition to press them. You know, he's going forward, he attacks. Scores a lot of goals, sometimes concedes, but you know that as a manager.

"But I think he's also a good man-manager. I think he's also good with the players and giving them the confidence, giving them the attention they need - and not only the starting XI, but also the other players within the squad. And that's what you need in a big club like that. So I would be very happy if they don't go for Carrick, and that they go for him."
Jaap Stam and Dimitaor Berbatov have shared their thoughts on United's managerial decision(Image: Getty Images)
Having enjoyed a successful period playing together at Old Trafford, former striker Berbatov is among those keen to see Carrick succeed - but has called for patience before any rash decision is made.

"I am a bit biased of course, because I used to play with him [Carrick] and I want him to get the job but let's wait until the end of the season and if they go the way they are right now, of course, why not?", Berbatov said to ESPN FC.

"We have seen what happened before with Ole Gunnar Solskjær, I think it was the same story so let's not jump to conclusions yet, let's just enjoy game by game how United is improving and at the end of the season we will wait and see what happens."

"He [Carrick] is in this position to show that he is capable of doing these things. So far in the games that we have watched, everything is just happening for the team and for him. Until the end of the season will be a test, and then we'll see if Michael can get the job permanently."
Meanwhile, fellow former striker Louis Saha is keen to see Carrick retained on a permanent basis.

He said: "I would love to see Michael given the chance. He's done very well. He's a very hardworking guy but humble as well. The results are going for him at the moment but not only the results, the way the team is playing and performing, we all can see the change straightaway. He's had the biggest impact since Sir Alex Ferguson."
"He does provide an answer to the question about the next manager. Necessity, I do think they need to think about Carrick very, very, very seriously there.

"We know the expectation is so big and sometimes both have certain types of conversations and they want to see a long term plan. Do they see this is a spell where everything is going well for Carrick? Who knows how he reacts when he's under more pressure.
Louis Saha believes Carrick should be appointed permanently(Image: Getty Images)
"So maybe he needs to be challenged in that sense to be considered for the full-time role. I don't know.

"What I see is that he understands the DNA of the club, he's been under pressure, maybe not as a manager but as a player, he understands how those managers have reacted before as he was part of the coaching staff. So he understands. He's not a rookie. So I do think he deserves his position but when names like Ancelotti, Zidane come into play, it's a kind of a different ball game."
The final ex-United star to speak out was former midfielder Owen Hargreaves and he claims that the run of form under Carrick makes it impossible not to give him the role permanently.
"I don’t see how you couldn’t give it to him," said Hargreaves to MEN. "What would have been the point of working that hard? You can get elite managers in, but that doesn't guarantee success.
"What Michael’s doing is very impressive. The fans are happy, which is important. The players are happy and that’s important, but the most important thing is that the team wins.
"United have had big-name managers on the bench. They had two of the greatest in the last 10 years, up there with Pep and Ancelotti: Van Gaal and Mourinho. A huge name comes with more expectation."

headline: Man Utd's stance on Marcus Rashford future as Michael Carrick transfer plan clear
body: Barcelona are keen to keep Marcus Rashford beyond his loan move(Image: JOSEP LAGO, AFP via Getty Images)

Manchester United are still making preparations for Marcus Rashford's departure this summer, as speculation about his future continues. The homegrown talent is currently on loan at Barcelona following his exclusion from the squad by former boss Ruben Amorim.

His switch to Spain came half a year after he sealed a temporary stint with Aston Villa. Rashford spent the second half of last season on loan with the Midlands club after falling out of favour at United, but a deal wasn't made permanent.

Under the terms of the current arrangement, Barca possess an option to sign him permanently this summer for £26million. Previous reports had indicated that the Spanish club were reluctant to meet the agreed price and were attempting to negotiate a slightly reduced fee.

Recent updates suggest that United were unwilling to drop their asking price, whilst Barcelona are now prepared to trigger the clause to complete a permanent transfer. The Sun reports that United are preparing for a future without Rashford, despite suggestions that Michael Carrick is keen on bringing him back.

The club had no plans to recall the player in January, with caretaker manager Carrick not looking beyond the summer when his contract runs out. It is understood that Rashford favours a departure from United in the summer window, regardless of whether a permanent switch to Barcelona materialises.

He reportedly wants his long-term situation sorted before linking up with England for the summer's World Cup in North America. If this proves to be the case, it would provide United with a welcome financial injection early in the transfer window as they seek to strengthen their squad.
Marcus Rashford is on loan with Barcelona from Man United this season. (Image: Angel Martinez, Getty Images)

Any money received for Rashford would count as pure profit under the Premier League's Profitability and Sustainability rules (PSR). The 28-year-old has already made his feelings known through comments made back in October.

"I'm really enjoying my time in Spain; the weather is the best," he said. "A very big change. I'm learning every day, I'm enjoying it a lot. I hope to be here for a long time. I get along very well with Roony [Bardghji], also Jules [Kounde] or Frenkie [de Jong]. It's a team in which we all mix.

"I'll keep trying to do this. We have to keep it up to be our best version. We have a lot more to do this season."

Michael Carrick believes Benjamin Sesko is ready to go to another level after praising the impact he made in rescuing a point for Manchester United at West Ham. headline: RAILSTON: What Benjamin Sesko did after Manchester United goal vs West Ham shows why he can be a success
body: Sesko scored a brilliant late goal

Manchester United drew 1-1 with West Ham in the Premier League on Tuesday. Michael Carrick had won his first four games in charge as interim boss and looked set to taste his first defeat since his appointment.
West Ham opened the scoring shortly after play resumed for the second half. Tomas Soucek latched onto a cross from Jarrod Bowen to score what looked like being the matchwinner at the London Stadium.
United struggled to respond and created very little as they chased an equaliser in the closing stages, but Benjamin Sesko scored late in added time to salvage a point.

Here are the talking points and moments you might have missed:
Sesko is a winner

Sesko scored three goals in Darren Fletcher's two games in charge, but he was moved to the bench by Carrick. The 22-year-old did not sulk and scored a late winner from the bench in the 3-2 win against Fulham.
After overlooking Sesko again last weekend, it felt like Carrick would reward Sesko for his strong run of form by starting him against West Ham, but he had to settle for another cameo from the bench.

United found it difficult to penetrate West Ham's backline and the game was screaming out for Sesko by half-time. The Slovenia international was the only player on the bench not wearing a coat when the substitutes took their place for the second half, but Carrick took his time to get Sesko on the pitch.

Carrick said it's "never easy" to pick his line-up when he spoke ahead of facing West Ham. The former midfielder had not put a foot wrong in four games, but got his team selection wrong for the first time.

That did not stop Sesko from salvaging a point in the final seconds of added time, though. The finish to secure a draw was spectacular, yet Sesko remained calm and urged his teammates to rush back to prepare for the restart. That mentality will serve him well in Manchester - he wanted more.
Carrick's reaction
More than half of Casemiro's goals for United have been headers, and the Brazilian thought he'd added another to his back catalogue when he found the net in the 63rd minute.
United had fallen behind at the beginning of the second half, and Casemiro came close to producing a response, but VAR chalked the goal off because he was offside by the matter of inches.

Carrick's body language when Casemiro's header hit the net was telling. The 44-year-old allows himself a rare release of emotion on the touchline when United score, but calmly walked back to the bench, seemingly unsure of whether the goal would stand.

United's interim coach did not react when VAR announced the goal had been disallowed. Carrick seemingly already knew the outcome before the final decision. He could also sense the game slipping away, but introducing Sesko in the 69th minute was a change that should have been made much sooner.

Mbeumo's work rate

The first half was dull at the London Stadium, partly because United struggled to get their attackers involved. Bryan Mbeumo was quiet and didn't offer much going forward, however, there was a moment when he demonstrated why he's a manager's dream to have in the dressing room.
Mbeumo started down the middle before moving to the left, and at one point he sprinted back to left-back to help stop an attack between Bowen and Crysencio Summerville.
The Cameroon international has been an excellent signing because of the quality he's provided in front of goal, but providing defensive cover when it's required is just as important.

Mbeumo isn't afraid to do the dirty work when his teammates need a hand. United have had wingers in recent years who did not have the same attitude, which is one of many reasons why Mbeumo is an upgrade.
Analyst team impact

United have significantly improved their set-piece record. The Reds scored from a clever set-piece against Tottenham last weekend and came close to scoring from another well-worked routine against West Ham.
Fernandes sent a well-weighted, low-driven ball in to Luke Shaw, who was able to lose his marker because West Ham were not expecting him to be the target.

Shaw connected well, only to be denied by Aaron Wan-Bissaka on the line. Carrick praised United analyst Kaita Hasegawa for his role in designing the set-piece goal against Spurs, and Hasegawa was spotted chatting among the analyst team in the press box when Shaw's shot was blocked.
Travis Binnion was spotted sitting alongside the analyst team again. Binnion is part of Carrick's backroom staff and sits in the stands to relay in-game tactical information to the bench.
Shaw's attempt was not successful, but involving a player with a poor scoring record from the set-piece highlights the analyst team's creativity.

headline: MARSHALL: Benjamin Sesko proved that Michael Carrick made his first Manchester United mistake vs West Ham
body: Benjamin Sesko resued a point for United at West Ham

This was the test that it felt like we had been waiting for, and for Manchester United and Michael Carrick, it was one that produced more questions than answers. After a dream start in the dugout, the idea of a Carrick coronation got a reality check at the London Stadium.

Four wins out of four had propelled Carrick to the top of the bookmakers' list of candidates to get the job long-term, but a night that ended with a bang still raised the kind of concerns that always felt likely to appear at some point in time.

Everything Carrick had touched had turned to gold in the first few weeks of his reign, but his side had won games that had been played to suit them and then took advantage of Cristian Romero's moment of madness on Saturday.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

Against a West Ham side fighting for their lives, this was always going to be different. For the first time, United dominated possession, but you get the impression this team would rather play without as much of the ball and have more space to run into. They turned 65% of the ball into just three shots on target.

It felt like Carrick played it safe by sticking with a winning formula. This was always likely to be a game crying out for the physical presence of a natural striker. Having decided not to start Benjamin Sesko, he then left it too long to bring him on, only for the £73million striker to show he was the missing ingredient after all.

For most of the second half, it had looked like being a night of misery for United and their excellent away support, who had somehow seen their team lose three successive games at the most welcoming of Premier League stadiums for visiting teams. It was nearly a fourth.
They certainly looked out of ideas when Carrick and Steve Holland stood motionless in the technical area with a minute to go. They had played their chips and the game was drifting away.
This coaching team has won praise for making the most of free weeks to devise perfect game plans for Manchester City, Arsenal, Fulham and Tottenham, but it looked like time worked against them here.

They had only a couple of days to get things right for this game and although there were times when some of the football was nice to watch, it was always in areas where West Ham were happy to watch it too, at least until the belated introduction of Sesko and then Joshua Zirkzee.

The good news for Carrick is that the Slovenian's goal salvages some momentum, but the questions will keep coming now. United have 13 days until they face Everton at the Hill Dickinson Stadium and you can be sure that David Moyes will take inspiration from Nuno Espirito Santo's game plan.

But just as four successive wins didn't guarantee Carrick was going to get the job in the summer, neither does one setback mean he should be discounted now. After a few days, United will regather at Carrington and work out how to break down a low block and prove this was an aberration rather than the start of a trend that will prove costly.

It had felt obvious early on that this was going to be a very different test. West Ham were quick to settle into a compact 5-4-1 shape and ask the visitors to break them down. Carrick had benefitted from playing teams happy to get into a football match so far, but West Ham were just as happy to spoil one.

United found the key to unlocking Tottenham came from a corner and they nearly repeated the trick. This time Bruno Fernandes sent in a low cross to Luke Shaw, who made a run across the box eight yards out and turned the ball goalwards, only for Aaron Wan-Bissaka to clear off the line.

That was the closest United came in an otherwise forgettable first half. Their approach play was easy on the eye but it offered no cutting edge.

If anything, it was West Ham who looked more dangerous on their rare forays forward and they made one count right at the start of the second half. Shaw was too passive in dealing with a long ball towards Jarrod Bowen, and then committed to a tackle in midfield that left Bowen with the freedom of the flank when he didn't win it.

Bowen was able to run unchecked into the United box, and his low cross was cleverly turned home by Tomas Soucek, who ghosted between Lisandro Martinez and Kobbie Mainoo, but was one of several West Ham players attacking the box.

That was a clear point of difference to United, who were doing their best work in areas that wouldn't hurt West Ham. Casemiro saw a header disallowed for offside, but the fact that he was regularly becoming United's most advanced player spoke to the lack of penalty box threat they carried.

That was something Carrick sought to address with the introduction of Sesko, but waiting until the 69th minute to do so invited scrutiny. Sesko had United's first shot on target in more than 50 minutes when he forced Mads Hermansen into a low save from the edge of the box.

He had the next shot on target as well. A brilliant instinctive finish from Bryan Mbeumo's cross salvaging a point for United. Sesko will surely start at Everton when United can expect a game that looks very similar to this one.

headline: JJ Gabriel speaks out on red card as Man United appeal decision expected
body: Manchester United talent JJ Gabriel(Image: James Gill - Danehouse/Getty Images)
Manchester United have reportedly decided to appeal JJ Gabriel's red card, which the 15-year-old received during the Under-18s' 4-3 victory over West Bromwich Albion on Tuesday.

Gabriel contributed two assists as United took a four-goal lead into the half-time interval of their Premier League Under-18 Cup clash. West Brom managed to pull one back after 52 minutes, and upon the restart the youngster became involved in a tangle with an opponent off the ball, resulting in his sending off.
It did not take long for the academy forward - who has already trained with the senior squad under both Ruben Amorim and Michael Carrick - to react.
Posting video footage of the incident on his Instagram stories, Gabriel fumed: "How can this be a yellow let alone a red, how?"

The red card is due to carry a three-match ban that would prevent the young talent from featuring in United's FA Youth Cup fifth round clash with Oxford United next Wednesday, February 18.
Gabriel featured in the previous round, starting and playing 115 minutes as Darren Fletcher's side defeated Derby County after extra-time at Old Trafford.
Either side of the important meeting with Oxford, Gabriel would be in line to sit out an U18s Manchester derby against Manchester City and finally a meeting with Wolves U18s.

headline: Man United receive VAR explanation after Casemiro goal ruled-out against West Ham
body: Casemiro's goal was disallowed against West Ham(Image: Getty Images)
Manchester United had a goal ruled out for offside in the second-half of their Premier League trip to West Ham United after Casemiro was deemed to be offside.

Tomas Soucek's opener put the Hammers ahead shortly after half-time following a quiet first-half. However, United thought they pulled level just 13 minutes later when Casemiro met Kobbie Mainoo's cross.
However, the video assistant referee (VAR) checked the goal and it was overturned for offside. Replays showed that the Brazilian had strayed slightly offside as the cross came in.
The Premier League match centre wrote on X: "VAR checked the referee’s call of goal – and established that Casemiro was in an offside position and recommended that the goal was disallowed."

body: Sandro Tonali is a new midfielder on Manchester United's transfer radar(Image: Getty Images)

Sandro Tonali is considering leaving Newcastle United this summer to play Champions League football next season. The midfielder has been linked with Manchester United in recent days as the club plans to bolster its midfield.

United are understood to be prioritising a new central midfielder for the 2026/27 season after opting not to invest in the previous two windows. Elliot Anderson, Carlos Baleba and Adam Wharton have all been linked, but Tonali is the latest name on their radar.

The Telegraph has reported that the 25-year-old is expected to be at the heart of a transfer saga in the summer. United are already confirmed to lose one midfielder when Casemiro departs and are expected to spend big on his replacement.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

Newcastle paid £55million for Tonali in 2023 and with the likes of Enzo Fernandez, Moises Caicedo and Declan Rice moving more than £100m, the Magpies are in a comfortable place to negotiate a hard price.
On deadline day, some reports suggested that the Italian midfielder had been offered to Arsenal. The Gunners decided not to make a move, but that has cast doubt on his future on Tyneside.
Sandro Tonali is reportedly on Man United's transfer radar(Image: Newcastle United via Getty Image)

According to Tonali's agent, Giuseppe Riso, his exit out of Eddie Howe's squad is a possibility at the end of the season. "Newcastle are having a hard time of letting go of Sandro, and he wants to lead the club to the Champions League," he told Sky Italy.

"We'll evaluate and decide what to do in the summer. These transfer discussions will take place later. We'll see how the season ends and then we'll decide what to do. There's no preference at the moment.
"It's still early. What we're saying today won't apply tomorrow. Newcastle couldn't let him go now, and there's no point in moving, especially since Sandro is very attached to the club."

"I don't think so, but lots of things happen without my knowledge," Howe said when asked if the speculation around Tonali's future would unsettle the midfielder. "As far as I'm aware, we've got player who is an outstanding footballer, an outstanding person.

"He's very happy here, he's got a great relationship with me, his teammates, and seems really happy within himself. That would surprise me [if Tonali became unsettled], but our best players will always attract glances from other clubs - that's just the reality of football.

"We want to keep our group together, we want to be progressive and Sandro plays a part in that. All encompassed, I don't see an issue but I don't control everything. There was certainly no intention from our side to lose Sandro at all. He's such an integral player to what we're doing. He's very happy here.
"He is absolutely fine. I had discussions with him yesterday [Monday] and he is absolutely focused on playing for us."
